Authors:
Patrick Simon Fahey, Rachael M Fowler, Frank Udovicic,
David J. Cantrill, Michael James Bayly
Title:
Use of plastid genome sequences in phylogeographic studies of
single species can be misleading without comprehensive sampling of
co-occurring, related species
Keywords:
Chloroplast capture, Eucalyptus, outgroups,
phylogeography, plastid genome, polyphyly
Abstract:
Aim: Test the hypothesis that the common practice of
drawing phylogeographic conclusions based on plastid DNA for a single
species in the absence of sampling of co-occurring related species is a
valid practice. Location: South-eastern Australia Taxon: Eucalyptus
section Adnataria (Myrtaceae) Methods: A genome skimming approach was
used to sequence and assemble chloroplast genomes from population level
sampling of the species Eucalyptus behriana as well as individual
samples of twenty-one closely related species which co-occur with it.
Phylogenetic analyses were first undertaken on just E. behriana to look
for geographic structuring in the species and what this could tell us
about the history of the species. A subsequent analysis, including the
set of related taxa was undertaken to test whether the conclusions
around the speciesÂ’ biogeographic history could still be considered
supported by the data. Results: We found strong geographic structuring
of plastid DNA relationships across the geographic range of E. behriana,
with a basal divergence between the most northerly isolated population
at West Wyalong and all other populations. However, when we compare this
to the phylogeny containing extensive outgroup sampling, we found that
there is little signal for the evolutionary relationships between
samples and the same geographic structuring of the tree is returned
across all sampled taxa. Main conclusions: The data are inconsistent
with the hypothesis that single species phylogeographic studies
utilising plastid DNA necessarily lead to valid findings in the absence
of substantial sampling of co-occurring related taxa. Despite finding a
meaningful phylogeographic signal when considering the ingroup taxa
only, when outgroups were included, this signal was confounded by a lack
of monophyly of the target species and the maintenance of the geographic
signal across species boundaries.
